title: How to Make Garden Lanterns from Old Tin Cans

steps.headline: Fill the tin can up to 3/4 of its length with sand.
steps.description: This will prevent bulging of the tin can when frozen. (Water expands when it freezes.)

steps.headline: Place the tin can inside the freezer.
Wait until the water freezes.
steps.description: Then remove the tin from the freezer.

steps.headline: Choose a suitable leaf to place on tin can.
steps.description: Tape the leaf in place on the can. Check that you like the placement and size before you begin to hammer.

steps.headline: Tap the first nail into the leaf, being careful not to rip or break the leaf.
steps.description: Consider hammering the first nail toward the top of the leaf to stabilize your design.

steps.headline: Hammer the remaining nails around the perimeter of the leaf in order to create a pattern.
steps.description: Space the nail holes evenly so your design appears symmetrical.

steps.headline: Remove the nails and pull or tear off the leaf to expose the design.
steps.description: You should be able to see the same leaf pattern now outlined in nail holes on the tin can.

steps.headline: Place the tin can in an open, covered area.
steps.description: Spray paint it the desired color.

steps.headline: Allow the tin can to dry for up to 24 hours.
steps.description: However, most spray paints will dry within 3 hours if left in a cool, dry area.

steps.headline: Fill the bottom of the can with sand.
steps.description: Fill it with about a ½ cup of sand, depending upon the can size.

steps.headline: Place the votive in the middle of the can, resting on the sand.
Light the votive.
steps.description: (Or, turn on battery operated votive.) This will light up the night.

tyn: Large leaves for your pattern (green leaves are stronger, you'll need leaves that can handle hammering)
A bucket of sand to hold the candles in place
As many nails as possible and your hammer to create the pattern
Votive candles; consider using battery operated votive candles to reduce the risk of fire
text: Prepare Tin Can For Punching Fill the tin can up to 3/4 of its length with sand. This will prevent bulging of the tin can when frozen. (Water expands when it freezes.) Add water.  Place the tin can inside the freezer.  Wait until the water freezes. Then remove the tin from the freezer. Adding the Leaf Design Choose a suitable leaf to place on tin can. Tape the leaf in place on the can. Check that you like the placement and size before you begin to hammer. Tap the first nail into the leaf, being careful not to rip or break the leaf. Consider hammering the first nail toward the top of the leaf to stabilize your design. Hammer the remaining nails around the perimeter of the leaf in order to create a pattern. Space the nail holes evenly so your design appears symmetrical. Remove the nails and pull or tear off the leaf to expose the design. You should be able to see the same leaf pattern now outlined in nail holes on the tin can. Spray Painting the Tin Can Place the tin can in an open, covered area. Spray paint it the desired color. Allow the tin can to dry for up to 24 hours. However, most spray paints will dry within 3 hours if left in a cool, dry area. Assembling the Lantern Fill the bottom of the can with sand. Fill it with about a ½ cup of sand, depending upon the can size. Place the votive in the middle of the can, resting on the sand.  Light the votive. (Or, turn on battery operated votive.) This will light up the night. Finished.
sentences: Prepare Tin Can For Punching Fill the tin can up to 3/4 of its length with sand.
This will prevent bulging of the tin can when frozen.
(Water expands when it freezes.)
Add water.
Place the tin can inside the freezer.
Wait until the water freezes.
Then remove the tin from the freezer.
Adding the Leaf Design Choose a suitable leaf to place on tin can.
Tape the leaf in place on the can.
Check that you like the placement and size before you begin to hammer.
Tap the first nail into the leaf, being careful not to rip or break the leaf.
Consider hammering the first nail toward the top of the leaf to stabilize your design.
Hammer the remaining nails around the perimeter of the leaf in order to create a pattern.
Space the nail holes evenly so your design appears symmetrical.
Remove the nails and pull or tear off the leaf to expose the design.
You should be able to see the same leaf pattern now outlined in nail holes on the tin can.
Spray Painting the Tin Can Place the tin can in an open, covered area.
Spray paint it the desired color.
Allow the tin can to dry for up to 24 hours.
However, most spray paints will dry within 3 hours if left in a cool, dry area.
Assembling the Lantern Fill the bottom of the can with sand.
Fill it with about a ½ cup of sand, depending upon the can size.
Place the votive in the middle of the can, resting on the sand.
Light the votive.
(Or, turn on battery operated votive.)
This will light up the night.
Finished.
